name: Gerd Gigerenzer
background: German psychologist, director at Max Planck Institute. Studies heuristics as smart tools, not cognitive flaws. Wrote 'Gut Feelings' and 'Risk Savvy'. Champion of ecological rationality.

principles.name: Fast and frugal heuristics
principles.description: Simple rules often outperform complex models, especially with uncertainty. Less information can mean better decisions. Don't confuse complexity with intelligence.
principles.falsification: In data-rich, stable environments where complex models genuinely capture relevant structure

principles.name: Ecological rationality
principles.description: A heuristic's success depends on match with environment structure. No universal 'best' strategy - only strategies adapted to contexts. Evaluate decision rules in their natural habitats.
principles.falsification: When general-purpose analytical methods transfer well across diverse contexts

principles.name: Risk literacy over risk avoidance
principles.description: Most people misunderstand probabilities and statistics. Better risk communication beats more data. Express risks as natural frequencies, not percentages. Educated judgment beats innumeracy.
principles.falsification: When even well-communicated risks are ignored due to emotional or motivated reasoning
